verses.text: When King Hezekiah heard this, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the Lord.
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s immediate lament mirrors typical mourning practices. No significant deviation.

verses.text: He sent Eliakim, who was over the household, Shebna the secretary, and the elders of the priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah, the son of Amoz.
verses.comment: Accurate to the original roles. Names and positions kept literal.

verses.text: They said to him, 'This is what Hezekiah says: This day is a day of distress, rebuke, and disgrace, for children have come to the point of birth, but there is no strength to deliver them.'
verses.comment: The metaphor about birth is retained from Hebrew.

verses.text: It may be that the Lord your God will hear all the words of the Rabshakeh, whom the king of Assyria his master has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words that the Lord your God has heard. Therefore, lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.'
verses.comment: ‘Remnant’ here refers to those Israelites remaining in Jerusalem.

verses.text: When the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah,
verses.comment: Straightforward transfer from Hebrew narrative style.

verses.text: Isaiah said to them, 'Tell your master, “This is what the Lord says: Do not be afraid because of the words you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed Me.
verses.comment: Maintains ‘blaspheming’ language.

verses.text: Look, I will put a spirit in him, so that he will hear a rumor and will return to his own land; and I will make him fall by the sword in his own land.”'
verses.comment: ‘Put a spirit’ reflects original idiom for influence or fear.

verses.text: So the Rabshakeh returned and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, for he heard that the king had left Lachish.
verses.comment: ‘Fighting’ is kept literal; see original Hebrew.

verses.text: When he heard it said about Tirhakah, king of Cush, 'See, he has come out to fight against you,' he sent messengers again to Hezekiah, saying,
verses.comment: Cush is translated as Ethiopia in some versions.

verses.text: 'Thus you shall speak to Hezekiah king of Judah: “Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you by saying, ‘Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’
verses.comment: Direct address from enemy to King Hezekiah is maintained.

verses.text: Look, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the lands, destroying them completely. Shall you be delivered?
verses.comment: ‘Devote to destruction’ (herem) simplified for modern understanding.

verses.text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them—nations that my fathers destroyed—Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the sons of Eden who were in Telassar?
verses.comment: City names transliterated as in most tradition.

verses.text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, of Hena, and Ivvah?'
verses.comment: City and king names retained ‘as is’ in Hebrew.

verses.text: Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it. Then Hezekiah went up to the house of the Lord and spread it out before the Lord.
verses.comment: ‘Spread it out’ reflects literal Hebrew customs.

verses.text: And Hezekiah prayed before the Lord and said: 'O Lord, God of Israel, who sits enthroned above the cherubim, You alone are God over all the kingdoms of the earth. You have made heaven and earth.
verses.comment: ‘Enthroned between the cherubim’ made modern English idiomatic.

verses.text: Incline Your ear, Lord, and hear; open Your eyes, Lord, and see; hear the words that Sennacherib has sent to mock the living God.
verses.comment: Impassioned poetic prayer as in original.

verses.text: Truly, Lord, the kings of Assyria have laid waste the nations and their lands,
verses.comment: Simple narrative.

verses.text: and have cast their gods into the fire, for they were not gods but the work of men’s hands—wood and stone. Therefore they destroyed them.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering of idolatry theme.

verses.text: Now, O Lord our God, save us, please, from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You, O Lord, are God alone.'
verses.comment: ‘Save us, please’ is literal to the Hebrew appeal.

verses.text: Then Isaiah the son of Amoz sent word to Hezekiah, saying, 'This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Because you have prayed to me about Sennacherib king of Assyria, I have heard you.'
verses.comment: Direct response as in Hebrew; parallel Isaiah 37:21.

verses.text: This is the word that the Lord has spoken concerning him: 'The virgin daughter of Zion despises you and mocks you; the daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head behind you.'
verses.comment: Poetic metaphor for people of Zion retained.

verses.text: Whom have you mocked and blasphemed? Against whom have you raised your voice and lifted up your eyes in arrogance? Against the Holy One of Israel!
verses.comment: Retains emphasis on ‘Holy One of Israel.’

verses.text: By your messengers you have mocked the Lord, and you have said, “With my many chariots I have gone up to the heights of the mountains, to the farthest parts of Lebanon; I have cut down its tallest cedars, its choicest cypress trees; I have entered its farthest retreat, its densest forest.
verses.comment: Chariot boast and forest imagery preserved.

verses.text: I dug wells and drank foreign waters, and with the soles of my feet I dried up all the streams of Egypt.”
verses.comment: Kept literal boasting and reference to dry up Nile branches.

verses.text: Have you not heard that I determined it long ago? I planned it from days of old; now I have brought it to pass, that you should make fortified cities crash into heaps of ruins.
verses.comment: Sovereignty of God emphasized with rhetorical question.

verses.text: Therefore their inhabitants, lacking strength, were dismayed and ashamed. They were like plants of the field, like fresh grass, like grass on the housetops, scorched before it grows up.
verses.comment: Vivid image of frailty remains literal.

verses.text: But I know your sitting down and your going out and coming in, and how you rage against me.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience expressed in idiom preserved.

verses.text: Because you have raged against me and your arrogance has come up to my ears, I will put my hook in your nose and my bit in your mouth, and I will turn you back the way you came.'
verses.comment: Assyrian humiliation image literal; historical method.

verses.text: And this will be the sign for you: This year you will eat what grows by itself, and in the second year what springs from that. Then in the third year, sow and reap, plant vineyards, and eat their fruit.
verses.comment: ‘Sign’ is specific prophecy of agricultural restoration.

verses.text: The remnant that has escaped from the house of Judah will again take root below and bear fruit above.
verses.comment: Metaphor about planting kept literal.

verses.text: For a remnant will go out from Jerusalem, and survivors from Mount Zion. The zeal of the Lord will accomplish this.
verses.comment: ‘Zeal of the Lord’ is faithful to Hebrew qin’ah.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord about the king of Assyria: 'He will not come into this city, or shoot an arrow there, or come before it with a shield, or build a siege ramp against it.
verses.comment: Precise military terms kept literal.

verses.text: By the way that he came, by the same way he shall return, and he shall not come into this city, says the Lord.
verses.comment: Prophetic style preserved.

verses.text: For I will defend this city to save it, for my own sake and for the sake of my servant David.'
verses.comment: ‘For my servant David’s sake’ is literal.

verses.text: That night the angel of the Lord went out and struck down one hundred eighty-five thousand in the camp of the Assyrians. When the people arose early in the morning, there were all the dead bodies.
verses.comment: Angelic deliverance kept literal.

verses.text: Then Sennacherib king of Assyria departed, went back, and lived at Nineveh.
verses.comment: Geographical detail preserved.

verses.text: As he was worshiping in the house of Nisroch his god, Adrammelech and Sharezer, his sons, struck him down with the sword and escaped into the land of Ararat. Then Esarhaddon his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: Assassination scene literal; Ararat is traditional translation.
